Award.AbstractNarration:
This project codes information from 18 book-length volumes of internal investigation reports in a region that experienced one of the largest political upheavals in the 20th century into a database. Insurgencies in collapsing authoritarian regimes have been a repeated and major concern for the U.S. in international affairs. This project capitalizes on the recent availability of these unusually detailed and highly-classified internal investigation reports, compiled by the government of a region that experienced some of the most severe disorders and highest death tolls. The database that will contain close to 6,000 political events and associated casualties, for all 86 cities and counties in the region, along with a range of economic, social, and political data about each locality. The quality, level of detail, and comprehensive coverage of these materials will permit the analysis of state collapse and political violence with an unusual degree of precision and depth. The completed dataset and full documentation will be widely shared and made publicly available at the end of the project. This will contribute to efforts to understand the dynamics of political violence and state repression, and the sources of instability and conflict in highly centralized authoritarian regimes. Data and analysis generated by this project will be valuable for the crafting of policy toward such regions.


The dataset compiled in this project will permit the analysis of the endogenous formation of factional identities during political upheavals, while at the same time gauging the impact of exogenous structural features of localities and populations on levels of political mobilization and collective violence. Three structural features of particular interest are ethnic and sub-ethnic populations in an ethnically diverse region, prior divisions within local political networks, and the degree of party-state penetration across 86 rural counties and cities. The dataset will permit the analysis of the factors that influenced the origins and evolution of a highly complex upheaval over the course of several years (1966-1969) that included the collapse of local civilian governments, a popular insurgency that divided into two violently opposed armed factions, widespread and systematic intervention by military units, and overwhelming levels of state repression in order to rebuild local governments. The anticipated analyses will employ event count models, event history analysis, and network analysis to analyze the initial formation of factions and the subsequent evolution of collective violence. The project will contribute to the understanding of violent insurgencies, civil war, and state repression, especially as it pertains to instability and upheavals in highly centralized repressive dictatorships that suffer sudden collapse.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project recorded into a computer database extensive materials from classified government investigation reports on one Chinese province that suffered from unusually high death rates during the Cultural Revolution from 1966-69. The classified reports were completed in the early 1980s by teams of investigators dispatched from China's central government to every one of the 86 cities and counties in the province of Guangxi. The findings were issued in 18 volumes that ranged from 300 to 800 pages, and they contained detailed chronologies of events in each city and county throughout this period, along with extensive statistical detail on the number of people killed, injuried, imprisoned, or otherwise victimized. Though never intended for publication or public release, all 18 volumes finally found their way outside of China several years ago and are now widely available.

These volumes are perhaps the most extensive and complete documentation of a political upheaval of this type from any country in any period of time. The dataset compiled as part of this project contains information about 4,937 events in which insurgents engage in violent acts or military or civilian actors engage in repression. They document more than 82,000 deaths directly attributable to these events and another 20,000 "missing", a death rate than is almost 70 percent higher than any other region of China. The dataset also includes extensive data about all 86 cities and counties in the province in the form of 70 variables that describe the population, political structures, and key events that affected the collapse or rebuilding of local governments.

Preliminary analyses of these materials answer a number of questions that scholars have long been unable to address with reliable information. One major finding is that the large death tolls in the province were not due to Guangxi's high population of ethnic minorities--there is no relationship between the ethnic composition of a locality and death rates. A second major finding is that the death tolls were not the result of spontaneous killings of politically stigmatized households (landlords, rich peasants) by ordinary citizens inadvertently touched off by the regime's rhetoric about class enemies and hidden conspiracies. A third major finding is that the killings that led to the unusually high death tolls took place in a very short period of time when rebel insurgencies were being suppressed and local governments rebuilt, and the killings took the form of a top-down campaign carried out by military and security networks that reached from the provincial capital into every county and every rural town in the province. More than 90 percent of all deaths were generated by the acts of miltiary or civilian authorities, and the majority of those killed were members of the civilian political faction that stood in opposition to the imposition of military control. These killings had the explicit support of Mao Zedong and the Central authorities in Beijing.

The data will be publicly available to researchers within 12 months after the first publication from this project, and will be of considerable interest to students of political violence, state repression, and the history of the Chinese Communist regime.
